channel.title: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Episode 13: EU Sanctions on Russia: Four Years After the Invasion
item.description: Marking four years since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, we examine how EU sanctions have evolved, expanded and intensified enforcement.

item.title: Welcome to the era of anarchic antitrust
item.description: Competition enforcement in America has descended into chaos

item.title: Why insider trading isn’t always bad
item.description: At least on prediction markets

item.title: That irritable feeling that France was right
item.description: Its call to urge strategic autonomy on Europe was largely ignored

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks Cut Short in Geneva
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Moscow of stalling negotiations.

item.title: What’s Behind Ethiopia’s Double-Digit Growth
item.description: And can Addis Ababa’s economic boon last?

item.title: South Korea is still haunted by its disgraced ex-president
item.description: A court verdict will not settle Yoon Suk Yeol’s toxic legacy

item.title: The Carney Doctrine Can Be More Than a Davos Speech
item.description: Middle powers need real institutions to resist superpower gravity.

item.title: Early Presidential Election Off the Table in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: And Japarov’s time in office seems to have been given an end-date: 2032.

item.title: The Pentagon says it’s getting its AI providers on ‘the same baseline’
item.description: Military is still abiding by ethics principles, according to DOD research head.

item.title: China’s humanoids are dazzling the world. Who will buy them?
item.description: The market for robot dancers, alas, is limited

item.title: Brain-like computers could be built out of perovskites
item.description: The long-hyped materials may have found their niche

item.title: The Human Exposome Project will map how environmental factors shape health
item.description: It makes the Human Genome Project look easy

item.title: How ICE’s new software tools could speed up deportations
item.description: The risk of overreach is high

item.title: Defense Business Brief: Saronic in San Diego; Zumwalts + battleships; SECNAV’s take on ship maintenance
Activists are pushing to loosen childhood-vaccine requirements
item.description: West Virginia has become a front line

item.title: The front line in America’s child-vaccine battle
item.description: How far can Robert Kennedy junior push state policies? West Virginia will provide an answer

item.title: The EU Cannot Afford to Bluff on Ukrainian Membership
item.description: Europe’s debate over the process of making Ukraine a full member is often framed as a test of resolve; but credibility is based as much on capacity as on intent. If promises cannot be sustained politically, they will eventually be broken, and the fallout will be strategically damaging.

item.title: How a four-year onslaught has changed Ukraine
item.description: The border guards who faced Russia’s tanks were changed for ever, like their country

item.title: Bored by Biathlon? The Winter Games Need Ping Pong.
item.description: Bringing some popular indoor sports to the Winter Olympics would dramatically expand their global reach.

item.title: The D Brief: Sentinel’s progress; Buildup near Iran; Canada’s decoupling plan; Russia targets Ukrainian energy; And a bit more.
Turkey’s Lawfare Is a Warning
item.description: The detention of Istanbul Mayor Ekrem İmamoğlu in Turkey is a classic example of democratic backsliding. Using legal institutions and procedures to shape who can run, who can speak, and who can organize has become the preferred method for limiting political competition while retaining the veneer of democracy.

item.title: How Worried Should We Be About Nuclear War?
item.description: Rafael Grossi, the head of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog, says abandoning the idea of nonproliferation would be a “dramatic mistake.”

item.title: Five US Policy Shifts Could Reshape Financial Markets
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s administration is advancing a series of domestic policy changes that affect credit, housing, monetary policy, corporate governance, and digital-asset markets. Taken together, they could transform the regulatory landscape and reverberate through the global economy.

item.title: From 4 Flotillas to 3: Inside the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force’s Historic Overhaul
item.description: The JMSDF ends a 60-year era in a sweeping “scrap-and-build” reform.

item.title: Billions in Pledges Expected for Trump’s Board of Peace but Doubts Persist
item.description: An inaugural meeting in Washington will focus on Gaza’s reconstruction.

item.title: Study: Central Asia’s Water Tower to Lose One-third of Glacier Mass by 2040
item.description: The smaller glaciers of the Tian Shan mountains respond more quickly to climate change.

item.title: West Bengal’s Election Is Turning Bangladesh’s Voting Pattern Into a Security Scare
item.description: Events across the border – including the rise of Jamaat-e-Islami – are serving as political ammunition in the Indian state assembly race.

item.title: The Evolution of Australia’s Sports Diplomacy in the Pacific
item.description: Australia has made its biggest Pacific sporting bet so far. Will it deliver results for both Australia and the Pacific Islands?

item.title: Europe Is Squandering Its Leverage Over China
item.description: Requiring Chinese companies that want to sell high-tech products in Europe to form joint ventures with local firms would go a long way toward strengthening the competitiveness of European industry. With its market having become a lifeline for China, the EU needs to recognize the strength of its bargaining position.

item.title: Japan’s Election Results: Takeaways for Takaichi
item.description: Insights from Kristin Vekasi

item.title: A Tragedy in Indonesia: Poverty, Data, and the Cost of a Schoolbook
item.description: In Nusa Tenggara Timur, a 10-year-old boy’s suicide exposes the limits of income-based poverty metrics. Multidimensional data show that deprivation in Indonesia often clusters long before a family is officially classified as poor.

item.title: Where Did China’s ‘Wolf Warrior Diplomacy’ Come From (and Where Did It Go)?
item.description: The fates of two prominent wolf warriors at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs – Qin Gang and Zhao Lijian – provide some insights.

item.title: Death Penalty or Acquittal? 3 Scenarios for Ex-President Yoon’s Insurrection Verdict
item.description: As South Korea awaits a historic judgment on the 2024 martial law crisis, tomorrow’s ruling will determine the legal fate of the former leader and the stability of the nation's democracy.

item.title: In Australia, Education Is Critical to Geostrategic Competition
item.description: Education in Australia not only underpins the foundations of national power, but contributes to its international reach, diplomatic links, trade relations, and security.

item.title: Russia’s economy has entered the death zone
item.description: Alexandra Prokopenko wonders how much longer it can go on metabolising its own muscle tissue

item.title: Trump Is Strong-Arming the World Out of Climate Action
item.description: Washington is leveraging its power to intimidate countries that are trying to protect the planet.

item.title: Iran Dangerously Misunderstands Its Situation
item.description: Tehran thinks it has negotiations with the United States under control. The results could be catastrophic.

item.title: Tech Is the Bright Spot in India-U.S. Relations
item.description: The AI models are American, but the food that feeds the beast is being enriched in India.

item.title: AI Will Transform Business, Not Just Jobs
item.description: Debates about the impact of AI have centered on potential job losses, with far less attention paid to its implications for the business landscape. But corporate leaders should be thinking about how the technology can enhance their organizational capabilities and, in turn, increase economy-wide productivity.

item.title: Did Women’s Votes and the Jamaat’s Liberation War Narrative Derail Its Plans for Power?
item.description: More than half of Bangladesh's voters are women, and they are increasingly visible and influential. They voted against the Jamaat-e-Islami’s regressive vision.

item.title: Why Did Buddhism Decline in Asia?
item.description: Lack of institutional sympathy over the centuries, especially at the elite level, may explain why it entered the modern era with relatively little gas in the tank.

item.title: Why Indonesia Is All-In on Trump’s Board of Peace
item.description: Some other Southeast Asian countries are steering clear.

item.title: Indonesia’s Unconventional 2026 Budget
item.description: It reflects many of the priorities and core economic beliefs of the Prabowo administration, including heavy investment in social welfare programs.

item.title: The Perils of Militarizing Law Enforcement
item.description: Latin America’s warning for U.S. democracy.

item.title: Episode 116: Is the Trump Administration's 'Donroe' Doctrine Transforming Relations with Latin America?
item.description: Following Washington's emphasis on the Western Hemisphere in its 2025 National Security Strategy, this episode examines Cuba, Venezuela and the intensifying US-China competition in Latin America.

item.title: Barometer Check: Transatlantic Security and the Munich Security Conference
item.description: The Munich Security Conference showed that Europe can chart a path for a new transatlantic relationship through taking responsibility for its own defence, building democratic resilience and supporting Ukraine.

item.title: With Speaker Uchral’s Trip, Mongolia and Russia Look to Expand Economic Links
item.description: Officials from the Mongolian government have repeatedly visited Moscow in search of energy guarantees, assistance in fuel storage, and accelerating bilateral cooperation.

item.title: MAG Aerospace loses protest in $96M Army contract
item.description: The Army found no issues and signed a waiver that killed a key aspect of MAG's argument.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Election Is Over. Its Future Has Yet to Be Written.
item.description: The incoming parliament will remake Bangladesh’s governance system – for better or worse.
